story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas received part of a pound million funding pot to help stop evictions caused by COVID-.The Scottish Governmentrsquos tenant grant fund aims to support people who have fallen into rent arrears as a direct result of the pandemic.SBC has been awarded a pound, grant, with a further pound, for administration of the fund.Back in September, housing secretary Shona Robisonsaid: ldquoThese grants will support tenants and landlords who are willing to work together to address rent arrears and agree a repayment plan to ensure the tenant is able to avoid eviction.ldquoCouncils have substantial experience in supporting people who have fallen behind on their rent, and are therefore well placed to work with both tenants and landlords in making use of this grant fund.ldquoAnyone who has been financially impacted by the pandemic and needs help to avoid eviction should contact their local authority housing department to discuss their circumstances.The money will go to the landlord, rather than the inidual, a meeting of SBCrsquos executive committee heard this week.The fund is available to all tenants living in the private and social rented sector at risk of homelessness, according to a report put to councillors.It is specically to help repay rent arrears that have arisen due to the coronavirus pandemic between March , , and August , .Arrears before March  last year will not be covered, the report states. Meanwhile, arrears after August  can only be covered in ldquoexceptional circumstances.SBC is ldquoliaising urgently with its partners to assess the scale of demand for the fund, with the money having to be used by March  next year.

title: say-red-sky-night-sailors-delight-mean
story: When you look out to a beautul pink-red sky this evening, you may utter the phrase "red sky at night, sailors delight" - but why People around the UK and the worldfrequently use the saying whenever a sunset lights up the sky."Red sky in the morning" on the other hand is a "sailors warning" - but is there any scientic meaning behind the phrases Heres what you need to know about what the sayings meanand wherethey originate from...Why do we say "red sky at night, sailors delight" "Red sky at night, sailors delight" is a common phrase, but you might also know it as "shepherds delight",which is the original version."Shepherds delight" and "shepherds warning" werefirst used in the Bible in the book of Matthew.The weather phrase was used to help shepherds in the hills prepare for the following days weather conditions.And according to the Met office, there is actually some scientic proof behind the age-old saying - particularly in the UK where the weather system comes from the west.Normally, when there is a red sky at night, it means that there is good weather coming.This is because a red sky at night generally signies high pressure is travelling from the west, meaning the next days weather will likely be dry and clear.Meanwhile, "red sky in the morning, shepherds warning", is because the good weather has already passed through towards the east, in turn making it likely that we will face wind and rain from low pressure.Why do red skies appear at night Ared skyoccurs whendust and small particles gettrapped in the atmosphere by high pressure.This then scatters blue light leaving only red light, which gives the sky its notably dferent red coloured appearance.Meanwhile for red sky in the morning, the same thing happens but this time it means that the high pressure is moving towards the east and low pressure is moving in from the west, often bringing bad weather.

story: Bronwyn Brodie travels to Jordan tomorrowas one of more than a dozen walkers raising money and awareness for Maggiersquos.Together, they will walk  kilometres ndash  miles ndash through the Wadi Rum, also known as the Valley of the Moon, in aid of the charity, which supports those affected by cancer.Looking ahead to the trip, which has been in the pipeline for more than a year, Bronwyn said: ldquoI am super excited but a little nervous because it is the unexpected.ldquoI feel asI know the trekkers only because we have got a Whats-App group and we have had a few Zoom-type calls.ldquoEverybody that is doing the trek is raising funds, not necessarily for Maggiersquos Edinburgh but other Maggiersquos. My money is going to Maggiersquos Edinburgh.Already, Bronwyn, who works with youngsters with additional support needs at Musselburgh Grammar School, has raised more than pound, for the good cause.The walkers, who come from throughout Britain, will wild camp and complete the memorable experience in just four days.The grandmother-of- told the Courier how Maggiersquos had impacted her le after she was diagnosed with breast cancer in .She underwent surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy but it was not until she was undergoing treatment that she visited the Maggiersquos Centre at Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.Bronwyn, of Dunbar, said: ldquoThey are just such a wonderful place and the feeling you get when you go in is like in a sanctuary.ldquoYou can speak to somebody, one of the staff or they have volunteers in there.ldquoYou can chat to people or you can sit and just be yourself.ldquoIt is whatever you want but my family, the first time they went in there, they also felt this overwhelming serenity.The visit soon became Bronwynrsquos ldquopassion and she has since taken part in two Culture Crawls ndash Maggiersquos flagship fundraising event.In January last year, she spotted the chance to raise money and awareness for the charity through a -kilometre trek through the Sahara Desert.The incredible experience was due to take place in November last year but was shelved due to the coronavirus pandemic.It was then pushed back again before finally the organisers were forced to move it from Morocco and the Sahara Desert to Jordan and Wadi Rum.Bronwyn, who is mum to Douglas, Darren, Ceinwyn and Lesley, will finish the trek in Petra.She said: ldquoIt is still a desert but it is a dferent kind of desert.ldquoIt is more rocky in parts but it is still a desert and the ultimate goal is still to raise funds and awareness for Maggiersquos.To support Bronwyn and Maggiersquos, go to justgiving fundraising bronwyn-brodie

title: tims-tales-roman-bridge-story
story: But Irsquom still in good condition and people use me to cross the River Esk at Musselburgh, just as they have done since the Romans came here and built their fort up on the hill nearby.Thatrsquos why local people sometimes call me the Roman Bridge.I like that name, it gives me a real sense of status, doesnrsquot it If Irsquom being honest, I am not the same bridge the Romans used I was made mostly of wood then.But I have memory of that time because fragments of that first version of me are still hidden inside the stones you now see.It was the Romans who made me really important.They made me the only bridge over the Esk here, and people had to use methey were travelling to or from their camp at Cramond.Then, later, people who were travelling to or from Edinburgh and wanted to keep their feet dry had to cross me too.I suppose thatrsquos why I was often repaired and rebuilt.I was here even before Musselburgh was called Musselburgh, but eventually I becameof one of the main entrances into the town.So many dferent types of people have crossed over me, for dferent reasons, that I have hundreds of stories I could tell. Some of these people or events are more famous than others.For example, when I was a young stone bridge in what you call the th century, I carried the Scots army over the river on their way to Dunbar in .I donrsquot think it went well because I saw some of themin a terrible state of panic, and the English crossed over soon afterwards.A few years later in , another English army crossed over me on their way south they didnrsquot look in a good way and I heard some gruesome stories of what had happened at a place called Bannockburn.Irsquove even been caught up in battle myself.Thatrsquos why I got seriously damaged in .It was a terrible bloody battle: I had never seen the water turn red like that before.I got badly damaged and then again the year after so much so they had to rebuild me. I heard this remake was thanks to a woman called Lady Seton, whose husband had been killed in the same battle I was damaged in. I got an extra arch at this time.I was glad, because I remained the only bridge here for a long time afterwards.I was often repaired so humans must have regarded me as still important.More armies followed: the last I remember was the Jacobite army in . They seemed happy when they ed.Recently a statue of an archer was raised close to me. I like it, and he keeps me company.Hersquos got Roman attire, and Irsquove heard it said he represents dferent periods of Musselburghrsquos history, including the Battle of Pinkie when I was so badly hurt.You humans seem so obsessed with fighting and killing each other and so much of your history is about that.But you know what  I think my best stories are about the thousands of interesting folk who have used me to go about their business over many hundreds of years.I donrsquot mean just stories about kings and queens and nobles, but also fishwives, traders, farmers, shopkeepers, servants, craftspeople Irsquove met so many dferent kinds of folk.Irsquove had lovers use my arches to meet up secretly Irsquove had a duel fought on me Irsquove heard people talk of their lives and passions their fears and dreams.Irsquove heard people argue and make up Irsquove watched children down the centuries play Irsquove seen and heard so many dferent sides of being human that I think I understand you better now, even though I am a bridge made ofcold stone.Yoursquod be surprised how similar you are to folk who came before you.Itrsquos these stories Irsquod like to tell. But there is no space here right now for all these tales. Irsquom just letting you know my intention.I suppose I also hope people will notice me a bit moreI tell these stories.You see, early in the th century, everything changed for me.I was no longer the only bridge, and they replaced the ramps I used to have with steps, so people couldnrsquot use methey had carts. I became a pedestrian bridge and folk often called me the Old Bridge.Irsquom kind of glad now, as I see how much traffic the other bridges have to carry. I couldnrsquot do that.But it means Irsquom not really important anymore in the way I used to be, although Irsquove heard folk say Irsquom a beautul and historic part of the town.Thatrsquos whatrsquos given me the idea to tell my stories. I can take people on a dferent journey, not just across the river but across the centuries.Next year is the Year of Stories, a perfect time for an old bridge to tell her secrets.Maybe you can come visit me then, walk over me, spend some time admiring me, while standing in the footsteps of thousands of people from history Then listen or perhaps even tell a tale of your own.

story: Laura Reid was sentenced to a restriction of liberty order between the hours of pm and am when she appeared for sentencing at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.Reid, of Moir Avenue, Musselburgh, had previously admitted wrongly claiming working tax and child tax credits amounting to pound,.Reid had claimed the amount from the Department for Work and Pensions over a two-year period despite permanently living with her partner Joshua Allison, who was in full-time employment.The -year-old was paid the amount she was not entitled to between April , , and April , .Sherf Roderick Flinn had deferred sentence to last week for reports to be prepared and last week was told that Reid ldquowas making repayments of her own volition.Solicitor Euan Gosney said that his client was currently taking a part-time university course and worked at an after-school club.Mr Gosney said that Reid fully admitted the offence but that Mr Allison had not been staying at the family home ldquothe whole time.The sherf decided not to impose an unpaid work punishment as he believed that would ldquoimpact on her children and acknowledged the offence was ldquoout of character. title: flu-jab-2021-side-effects-including-headache-treat
story: With Covid thrown into the mix as well, its important to protect yourself as much as possible.Like Covid, experts are encouraging people to get the flu vaccine this winter with certain groups offered it for free on the NHS.Society has become pretty familiar with vaccines this year, so you perhaps know that side effects after a jab are possible.The same is true of the fluvaccine, but the good news is that they normally dont last very long and are usually much milder in comparison to actually catching the flu.Heres what you need to know about the flu vaccine side effects and how to treat them...According to the NHS, side effects of the flu vaccine can include:A fever is most likely to develop within the first  hours after the flu jab and should usually go away within  hours.If the fever starts  hours after the flu vaccine, it is unlikely to be a side effect of the jab and could be Covid, soyou should self-isolate and book a PCR test.Generally the side effects should only last a day or so, however there are still some tips to treat them.If you have a sore arm from the jab, the NHS recommends continuing to move your arm regularly.Taking a painkillersuch as paracetamol or ibuprofenmay also help.The flu vaccine can take between - days to work.Like the Covid vaccine, it may not completely prevent youfrom catching the flu but will likely mean you have much milder symptomsyou do get ill.It also means that you are much less likely to pass the flu on to other people.

title: speeding-motorcyclist-drove-astonishing-120mph-a1
story: Richard Montgomery, , was racing away from a BMW along the busy A while on board his Suzuki bike when he was caught travelling mph above the legal limit of mph last year.Traffic police stationed on an overhead bridge spotted Montgomery speeding near to the Gladsmuir Junction of the main road and gave chase.The officers eventually managed to catch up with the Scout leader and he was arrested and charged with dangerous driving.Montgomery, of High Street, appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last month, where he admitted driving at a ldquogrossly excessive speed on September  last year.He was back in the dock for sentencing on Monday, where Sherf Matthew Auchincloss described the speed he reached as ldquoastonishing.Solicitor Kevin Connor told the court: ldquoFirst of all, there is excuse for what he did. His position is that he was being tailgated by a BMW and he took the silly decision to accelerate away from it.ldquoWhat he did was way overboard and there was no need to accelerate to the speed he did, but he did and he accepts his guilt.ldquoHe understands what he did was risky and dangerous. He did slow down of his own accord very soon afterwards.The lawyer added that Montgomeryrsquos illegal behaviour on the road was ldquovery brief, as he was clocked doing mph at .pm and then pulled over and charged by the police at .pm.Mr Connor said that Montgomery was a local Scout leader and that he owned a golf chauffeur business, Montgomery Golf Ltd, where he drove mainly American tourists to play at prestigious golf courses throughout Scotland.The court also heard that Montgomery had previous driving convictions on his record and that he currently had live penalty points on his licence.Sherf Auchincloss said: ldquoThe speed you were doing was astonishing.ldquoThe level of risk to you and to other road users was very high indeed.The sherf banned Montgomery from driving for  months and ordered him to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community as an alternative to a custodial sentence.The businessman was also told he must complete the extended driving test before he is allowed back on the road.Montgomery pleaded guilty to driving a motorcycle dangerously and at grossly excessive speeds at the A near Gladsmuir on September  last year.

title: say-red-sky-night-sailors-delight-mean
story: People around the UK and the world frequently use the saying whenever a sunset lights up the sky."Red sky in the morning" on the other hand is a "sailors warning" - but is there any scientic meaning behind the phrases Heres what you need to know about what the sayings meanand wherethey originate from..."Red sky at night, sailors delight" is a common phrase, but you might also know it as "shepherds delight",which is the original version."Shepherds delight" and "shepherds warning" werefirst used in the Bible in the book of Matthew.The weather phrase was used to help shepherds in the hills prepare for the following days weather conditions.And according to the Met office, there is actually some scientic proof behind the age-old saying - particularly in the UK where the weather system comes from the west.Normally, when there is a red sky at night, it means that there is good weather coming.This is because a red sky at night generally signies high pressure is travelling from the west, meaning the next days weather will likely be dry and clear.Meanwhile, "red sky in the morning, shepherds warning", is because the good weather has already passed through towards the east, in turn making it likely that we will face wind and rain from low pressure.Ared skyoccurs whendust and small particles gettrapped in the atmosphere by high pressure.This then scatters blue light leaving only red light, which gives the sky its notably dferent red coloured appearance.Meanwhile for red sky in the morning, the same thing happens but this time it means that the high pressure is moving towards the east and low pressure is moving in from the west, often bringing bad weather.

title: cash-charities-readers-can-help-replace-vital-sensory-equipment-fife-autism-charity
story: She saw her daughter Alannah change as she approached her second birthday and had gone from an affection, alert toddler to being withdrawn and not wanting to be touched within months.It was her motherrsquos instinct that led to Ms Quin seeking help and Alannah was diagnosed with autism at the age of five.Read more: Glasgow cancer support centre offers leline at time of needHowever, Alannahrsquos condition was severe and there was little verbal communication. It was when Ms Quin wanted to get more help for her daughter and find support groups that she felt she had hit a brick wall.The -year-old decided to do something about it and initially set up a facebook page in Fe for parents with autistic children to be able to support one another. It led then to park meet ups and within six months, Ms Quin founded the Autism Rocks charity in .And the charity is one of our eight finalists in our Readers Choice Cash for Charities initiative.The Herald is giving charities the chance to take a share of a pound, cash giveaway. Our parent companyrsquos charitable arm, The Gannett Foundation, is providing pound, in cash to support local charities across the country and we are delighted to have a pound, share to give away in Scotland.The other seven finalists are Scotlandrsquos veteransrsquo charity Erskine, Calumrsquos Cabin, Maggiersquos Cancer Centres, Beloved Rabbits, Chest Heart and Stroke Scotland, Man on Inverclyde and Ardgowan Hospice.Read more: Cash for Charities: Veterans charity Erskine in bid for funds for le-saving testsWhile primarily a charity for families in Fe, parents and children come from all over the central belt and travel from Glasgow and Edinburgh to use the centre in Buckhaven.Ms Quin, founder and chairman of Autism Rocks, said: ldquoI was really struggling and I knew there must have been parents out there in a similar situation to me and I tested the water with a facebook page. I never imagined it would take off the way it has. We have gone on to become a registered charity and have seen , people have come through the door of our centre, the Kaleidoscope which we opened in . We now support more than  families.ldquoWe run drop-in sessions, support groups for parents, and teens and adults with autism and have our family days at the weekends. We just allow the families and the children to be themselves. They donrsquot have to hide or feel they are being judged. Our centre is their safe place.One of the areas which children enjoy most is Autism Rocks sensory garden. It is a calm and relaxing place where the youngsters can sit and listen to sounds and be soothed by sensory lights.A light and sound arch in the garden projects rainbows on to an area which children love to sit and watch. However, it has been damaged to the elements and over-hanging trees but is a vital piece of sensory equipment the charity would like to replace and can cost in the region of pound,.Ms Quin added: ldquoAll the children who come to us just love to spend time in the garden. It is a place which is very tactile so that they can feel and touch dferent plants and objects. For a child with autism our sensory arch can be a way to relax and calm them and any funds we receive from the Gannett Foundation would go towards that.ldquoWe are a charity which is non-profit and we donrsquot qualy for certain funding pots. When we were told about the Gannett Foundation nomination, I think we were just overwhelmed and it was a massive boost. It had been a very dficult time for us having to close the centre in lockdown and we were delighted when we were able to welcome people back in June of this year.ldquoHowever, just knowing that someone had thought of us and recognised the importance of our work as the Gannett Foundation has really brought a smile to our faces.Throughout November we are running tokens every day in The Herald and we asked YOU to decide where this money should be spent.Now we are putting the power to allocate the cash back into the hands of our readers ndash during November, you are invited to collect tokens from our newspapers which can then be sent to collection points across our region or posted. Each token collected will then be used to allocate cash to the nominated charity ndash soyour favourite charity collects % of all to tokens collected, it will receive % of the pound,.All you need to do is drop your tokens in one of the special Cash for Charities boxes placed in ious supermarkets and newsagents.The tokens can also be posted to us at Herald Readers Choice Cash for Charity,  Fullarton Drive, Cambuslang, Glasgow, G FG with the closing date for delivery of tokens Sunday, November , .You can also drop off tokens at our Cambuslang site or our office at  Bath Street, Glasgow, G HG.

title: adele-taking-spotify
story: Why Because Adele asked them, and because shersquos the biggest-selling female star on the planet. ldquoAnything for you, announced the streaming giant on its Twitter page, accompanied by a praying hands emoji.Thatrsquos nice. But why The star explained: ldquoThis was the only request I had in our ever changing industry! We donrsquot create albums with so much care and [put] thought into our track listing for no reason. Our art tells a story and our stories should be listened to as we intended. Thank you Spoty for listening.In other words In other words musicians and their record labels do think about the track listing on their albums because they want the songs to be heard in a specic order, for reasons both commercial and artistic. For example there is a logic behind Smells Like Teen Spirit opening Nirvanarsquos Nevermind, and Le In A Day ending Sgt Pepperrsquos Lonely Hearts Club Band. You open and close each lsquosidersquo with strong songs and you arrange everything  around those four lsquotentpolesrsquo.But notyou shuffle Indeed. An on-screen button ndash actually a symbol of two inter-weaving lines ndash allows Spoty users to play album tracks randomly. Soyour first listening experience of, say, The Beatlesrsquo White Album kicks off with Revolution  and is then followed by Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da when it could have opened on Back In The USSR and Dear Prudence, yoursquore not really hearing it as the musicians intended. Or wanted. Now the Spoty app will default to playing album tracks in the order they appear. In a statement, the company said it was ldquoexcited to be rolling out a feature which had long been requested. It continued: ldquoAs always, we will continue to iterate our products and features to create the best experiences for both artists and their fans.Andyou do want to shuffle There is still an option, so in one sense itrsquos kind of a pyrrhic victory. But it will cheer fans of concept albums such as Pink Floydrsquos The Dark Side Of The Moon.Is  a concept album Yes,the concept is to sell millions of records and notch up tens of millions of Spoty plays. And yes, itrsquos conceptual in the sense that it charts the -year-old singerrsquos orce.Anything  Music fans are cheering, especially those who love the album format, which still has le in it thanks to the ever-increasing sales of vinyl records. Tim Burgess, frontman with The Charlatans and the founder of Timrsquos Twitter Listening Party, in which social media users listen to a classic album together in real time, wrote: ldquoLong live the album. But he also had a message for Adele: ldquoSpoty replied lsquoanything for yoursquo ndashso, maybe ask them to pay artists fairly.

title: glasgow-area-sees-property-interest-soar
story: Now, it seems property hunters are fighting it out for new homes Battlefield area of Glasgowrsquos south side.Interest in homes in the G area,which also takes in Govanhill, Queenrsquos Park, Langside and Mount Florida, hassoared by % in the past year, according to Rightmove,while prices have surged by % over the past three years to a new record average of pound,.Lee Hardy, Associate Director of Tay Letting says a two-bedroomed flat in the area was recently let for pound a month. Another received  plus inquiries the day it went live.ldquoIf you had said to me two years ago that you would be getting pound for a flat in Battlefield I would have laughed, he says.The hipsters are well and truly settled into the areaGlasgow City Council say there has been substantial public and private investment in the area in recent years, replicating other parts of the city such as Dennistoun and Finnieston which were not always seen as desirable.Govanhill itself has experienced a flurry of openings of coffee shops, bars and restaurants as well as the re-opening of the B-listed Edwardian public bathhouse after a long-running community campaign.ldquoBattlefield, in particular, over the past two years has really boomed to the point where, itrsquos probably overtaken Shawlands, price wise, said Mr Hardy.ldquoOn one street alone wersquove got three two-bedroomed tenement flats that have achieved pound and one achieved pound, six weeks ago.: Plan to emulate Dennistoun effect in other areas of Glasgows eastldquoEven Govanhill, we had a one-bedroom flat that was renovated to a pretty high standard and is being listed at pound per month."Obviously Govanhill has a reputation but to get pound for a one-bedroom is exceptional.ldquoWe had another off Victoria Road, which we got pound for. With the lack of supply in the usual hotspots, I think people are just branching out now.ldquoThe west end had always commanded the highest rents but I think people seeing there is more value for money in the south side, which in turn has pushed the prices up.The demand far outweighs the supply. Its mainly young professionals and couples."He said there has been an increase generally in people opting to rent rather than buy because of the post-Covid property boom. ldquoI heard of one flat going for % over the home report last week.: Core area of Glasgow city centre to go car free within five yearsRobbie Gray, , who owns Canary Girl Coffee Co on Cathcart Road, said: ldquoIn the past it was seen as a bad neighbourhood, but only be people who didnrsquot live here, he says.ldquoThey saw it like some sort of ghetto, mainly because it is culturally erse. But that attitude is definitely changing.ldquoThere used to be just one speciality cafe now there are three or four,and a lot of the old-man pubs are being bought up by younger people and gentried in a way.Mr Gray said the areas is also a ldquoreal stronghold for the LGBTQ community, ldquowhich I think is a good indicator of the sort of gentrication which is happening.He said his only fear is that the area becomes too expensive to buy property.Yvonne Kincaid, who lives in Battlefield with her husband and two children, says the area has been transformed since she moved there  years ago.ldquoThe only hipster element back then was a Beanscene, she says.ldquoWith the huge Battlefield mural, in the design of the Barrowlands logo on Lochleven Road, the hipsters are well and truly settled into the area but thatrsquos not a sleight, itrsquos meant to reflect the vibrancy and collective pride we have in the area.: The Glasgow townhouse that was most viewed property in UK after mansion owned by Robbie WilliamsldquoLots of exciting clubs, pubs and restaurants are opening. She says there is a real sense of community in the area, that isnrsquot always seen in the most affluent areas of the city.ldquoThere is a feeling of a small village within the grid network of Battlefield, but even within its hinterland, we all seem to acknowledge each other and especially during lockdown, checked on neighbours who were perhaps vulnerable.ldquoThe local councillor Anna Richardson is hands on and a great asset to the area.A Glasgow City Council spokesman said: ldquoThere has been substantial public and private investment in the wider area in recent years, with the results shown in improved infrastructure such as the South City Way and the new square at the south-west corner of Queenrsquos Park, as well as a transformed range of shops, bars and restaurants in areas such as Govanhill. ldquoThis investment has made the wider area increasingly attractive as a place in which to live, work, visit and invest, as evidenced by property values.

title: tied-gagged-civil-servant-deeann-fitzpatrick-allowed-pursue-whistleblowing-claim
story: DeeAnn Fitzpatrick is seeking a case for unfair dismissal against the Scottish Government and last week sought to amend her claim to include whistleblowing and discrimination allegations.The tribunal has now rejected her bid to pursue sex, age, race, religion and disability discrimination claims, but allowed her to proceed with the assertion that she was dismissed because she made protected disclosures.Ms Fitzpatrick claims she was bound to a chair because she blew the whistle on misogyny and abuse in a Marine Scotland office, but bosses found that she lied about the timing and nature of the incident, which was deemed ldquohigh jinks.A photograph of her taped to a chair went viral at the peak of the #metoo movement in , prompting a national outcry and investigation by the government body.The probe found the men involved had ldquono case to answer and Ms Fitzpatrick was instead dismissed for gross misconduct.The Canadian will now pursue her case in full at the employment tribunal next month in a bid to be reinstated by Marine Scotland.In a written judgment on his decision, employment judge Alexander Kemp said it was ldquoin the interests of justice to refuse the discrimination claims.He added that he has permitted the whistleblowing claim on a ldquorestricted basis, relating only to two emails ndash one containing information about an alleged assault in the workplace and another about the chair incident.In her bid to pursue the additional claims, Ms Fitzpatrick told the tribunal that colleagues in Marine Scotlandrsquos Scrabster office called her a ldquof***ing Canadian retard, ldquowh**e and ldquoold troll.She said: ldquoI begged to have a work environment that was safe, to be able to go to work and do the job I was being paid to do, and that environment was not provided by my employer. I was left to my own defence within an office that was feral, in an office that they knew was misogynistic and racist. And because I spoke out, I was dismissed and I am now in an employment tribunal.Solicitor Andrew Gibson told to the tribunal that Ms Fitzpatrick was dismissed for lying about elements of the chair incident.He said: ldquoWhat is in dispute is that the incident took place against the claimantrsquos will and that it was in any way, shape or form an assault. My clientrsquos position is that it was done entirely with her consent.The lawyer added that a forensic expert found that the photograph was taken in , not in , which disputes Ms Fitzpatrickrsquos claim that it was done in response to her blowing the whistle.Mr Gibson said: ldquoThatrsquos a signicant hood which had signicant consequences for two employees at Marine Scotland who were questioned by the police.He submitted that the additional claims should not be allowed as they were lodged late in proceedings and related to ldquovery historic incidents.

title: hibs-question-sporting-integrity-celtic-handed-majority-tickets-premier-sports-cup-final
story: Following lsquolong and intense discussionsrsquo with the SPFL, the Easter Road side have been handed an allocation of around , for the December  showcase against Celtic.It means the capital outfit will be outnumbered by almost two to one in the Hampden stands.Hibs took less than , to Sundayrsquos - victory against Rangers but made up for that imbalance off the field with a stunning display on the pitch.Jack Rossrsquo side will again need a huge performance to overcome their underdog status following the failure of boardroom talks.A statement read: ldquoAs a club, we had a number of long and intense discussions with the SPFL, fighting for an even split of tickets with Celtic for the Premier Sports Cup Final at Hampden Park, knowing our history of selling out tickets for cup finals and for sporting integrity.ldquoHowever, they have come to the decision that we will have an allocation of approximately , tickets for the match.ldquo[It is] a decision that we are incredibly frustrated about. We made our thoughts very clear."On a positive note, we are pleased that the kick-off time has been scheduled for :. We asked for this to be moved forward from the planned time of : to help our supporters with travel to and from Hampden.ldquoOn top of that, we are also happy that our thoughts were listened to regarding concession prices for our supporters in all areas.Hibs fans will be housed in part of the south stand and behind the goals in the west stand, whilst the Celtic support will occupy the whole of the north and east enclosures, as well as the east end of the south stand.

We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . title: ally-mccoist-speaks-life-clerical-assistant-key-government-hq-celebrates-40-years
story: The Rangers and Scotland striker turned TV and radio personality was one of  staff recruited when the then Overseas Development Administration opened Abercrombie House in East Kilbride in .The building was officially opened by then Foreign Secretary Lord Carrington  years ago todayand now houses almost , employees as the Foreign, Commonwealth  Development Officersquos joint HQ.Although Mr McCoist, now , only worked there for five months as a clerical assistant before his football career took off, he has paid tribute to the former colleagues he worked with when the building first opened.Former international development secretary Anne-Marie Trevelyan beside a commemorative plague when she visited Abercrombie Housein February .The footballer, who played part-time with St Johnstone at the time said: ldquoItrsquos amazing to think that  of the people I worked with when Abercrombie House first opened are still there today. If you ask me, they all deserve a George Cross in recognition of that service.ldquoIt was a massive boost for East Kilbride that building opening. I still remember my first day, getting off the No bus from Calderwood, and walking into this amazing new place as a civil servant.ldquoMy mum and dad clearly knew what I wanted to do with my le, but theyrsquod made sure Irsquod kept up with my schoolwork and were proud as punch Irsquod got the ODA job.ldquoWee Brian was my boss and I used to sit next to a girl called Louise, who was the biggest Celtic fan you ever met in your le and we used to have great fun.ldquoThere was a cracking group of people there at the time and I loved the camaraderie. One of the best things was that there was a pub on site.ldquoThe lucky thing was that at ODA, at that time, we worked flexi hours, which was brilliant, as I could work my football around it.ldquoSo, I could go in early, do my sht, andI needed to get the bus up to St Johnstone then I was able to do that.ldquoSadly, I was too far down the pay scale to be given any foreign assignments. They obviously sussed me out straight away and wouldnrsquot let me out of East Kilbride.His civil service career ended when Sunderland signed him for pound, from St Johnstone.But he said: ldquoYou can never say how le might have panned outfootball hadnrsquot worked out, but I wouldnrsquot have been desperate to leave Overseas Development.ldquoIrsquom deadly serious because I really enjoyed my work there. There was no way I was dying to escape.ldquoYou never know,I hadnrsquot joined Sunderland, I might have been one of those who have served the full  years.Earlier this year, it was revealed than more that  of , civil service jobs relocated to Scotland were Foreign Office posts moving to the departments existing base in East Kilbride, South Lanarkshire.The UK Government said it was part of a "commitment" to Abercrombie House, which acts as the joint headquarters for the Foreign, Commonwealth  Development Office .The additional roles would bring the Foreign Offices staff in East Kilbride to , by .The FCDO is the result of the merger of the Scottish-based Department for International Developmentand the Foreign Office .Last year, Boris Johnson had been asked for urgent reassurance for the  staff at the DfID who had been based at Abercrombie House since the s and was believed to produce poundm for the local economy.In , the DfIDs Overseas Territories Departmentwas relocated from London to boost the workforce in East Kilbride.The department played a key role in tackling Ebola, gender inequality, the crisis in Syria and the provision of lesaving aid in emergencies.Rutherglen-born Jackie French was one of those who are part of the Full  club, having been at Abercrombie House from the start.Ms French, currently senior programme Mmanager in the girlsrsquo education department said: ldquoI will always remember my first day. As the  bus approached Hairmyres, three smartly dressed young people stood up and we all looked at each other and said lsquoODArsquo. One of them was Ally McCoist.ldquoWe were sent for training in the Registry Department and it was set out in rows, just like in school, which made us laugh."Foreign secretary Liz Truss said: ldquoOur , staff in Scotland can proudly celebrate  years of Abercrombie House having been at the forefront of making the UK a world-leading diplomatic and development superpower.ldquoIrsquom looking forward to building on Abercrombie Housersquos impressive history, as we position the UK at the heart of an unrivalled global network of economic, diplomatic and security partnerships to deliver for the British people.ldquoThe commitment to redeploy a further  jobs to our joint HQ by , as part of the UK Governmentrsquos levelling up agenda, ensures Scottish voices will play a pivotal role in using our poundbillion aid budget to combat climate change and bounce back from the Covid pandemic.

title: passengers-advised-travel-foot-broken-calmac-lifeline-ferry-least-10-days
story: CalMac services were cancelled between the mainland and the Isle of Bute while the route has been cut to a single rather than a dual ferry service, after new engine problems with -year-old MV Bute surfaced at the weekend.The state-controlled ferry operator has advised passengers to avoid using cars on the service and suggested a  mile detour to use another route The vessel, which can carry  passengers and  cars had only just ed to action last week after an annual overhaul was delayed.In August, another engine problem led to cancellations of sailings between Wemyss Bay and Rothesay with the possiblility of further disruption while repairs were attempted.:Scandal: Ministers ignored -year-old CalMac warning about perilous state of Scotlands leline ferriesPassengers have been advised to travelpossible "by foot" as the smaller MV Coruisk, which can carry  passengers and  cars has been brought in as a relief vessel.But it is due to go over its annual overhaul on Monday. It is expected that MV Argyle, which like Bute can carry  passengers,  cars is due to take MV Coruisks place after she comes out of her overhaul. The vessel is due out on Friday.One Argyll and Bute councillor Liz McCabe said she had had contact over the weekend from CalMac to say they have not been able to get to the root cause of damage to the engine on MV Bute and that there will have to have a one vehicle service for "some time".She said she was told it will be out of service until December  at the earliest.MV Argyle was currently in dry dock at Gourock until November , however when she comes out of dry dock and MV Coruisk will go in."It looks like we will have one vehicle for some time which is absolutely shocking and just not good enough," she said.Services were cancelled on Friday morning when problems with one of the main engines of Bute first emerged on Thursday night.:Revealed: Execs extended working le of Scotlands beleaguered ferry fleet by  years in ruseCalMac withdrew the vessel from Saturday because as the problems continued.As a new one-vessel was put into operation, CalMac "strongly advised" passengers that as vehicle space would be "very limited" that "where possible to travel by foot".The state-controlled ferry operator advised thattravel with a vehicle is necessary passengers should "please consider" travelling through an alternative Bute route from Colintraive to Rhubodach.That would involve a  mile detour from Wemyss Bay. Rhubodach is eight miles away from Rothesay.It is the latest in a summer of issues with breakdowns and Covid issues involving Scotlands ageing ferry fleet.Transport minister Graeme Dey has said attempts were being made to ease the ferry crisis by purchasing another ferry.The breakdown in April of Scotlands biggest publicly-run ferry MV Loch Seaforth, which operates on the Stornoway to Ullapool route, caused disruption across the islands network for seven weeks.Islanders from Arran to Islay have lodged complaints to ministers about disruption and cancellations to services as the ageing Scottish ferry fleet falters.While industry experts agree the working le of the ferries is  years,  of the -strong ferry fleet run is older than that, with eight, including Hebridean Isles, past their th birthday.Glen Sannox in dock last year.The delivery of new island ferries MV Glen Sannox and Hull , still languishing in Ferguson Marine shipyard, which were due online in the first half of , was found to be over four years late with costs doubling to over poundm.Tommy Gore, Clyde area operations manager for CalMac, said: ldquoMV Bute has been taken off service for further investigation into the cause of an engine fault, and we have been advised that this work may take up to  days. A single vessel will operate between Rothesay and Wemyss Bay in the meantime. We apologise for any inconvenience that this is causing to passengers.

title: covid passport extension a possibility as businesses urged to reconsider working from home
story: The Scottish Government is to consider extending its vaccine passport scheme to include a broader spectrum of businesses.This was confirmed by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, this Tuesday afternoon, as she unveiled a new strategic framework which will guide the Government#s decision-making on COVID- restrictions.Ms Sturgeon said that, amid mounting cases nationwide, consideration would be given to extending the country#s COVID Vaccine Certication Scheme. She explained that a formal decision on this would be announced next Tuesday, and that consultation with businesses would take place later this week.The First Minister said that extension of the scheme is likely to include a broader scope of businesses, such as indoor cinemas, theatres and other hospitality venues. This would mean that, save for limited exemptions, these venues would require members of the public to provide proof of vaccination before entry. She said that the scheme may also begin to accept proof of a recent negative COVID- test as an alternative to the vaccine passport.Ms Sturgeon, who said that while she hoped to keep businesses across Scotland open throughout the winter, the Government has not completely ruled introducing harsher restrictions should the COVID- situation worsen. She has urged all business owners and employers to think carefully and #look again# at whether their employees can be supported to work from home, this winter.#While we hope we will get through winter without introducing further restrictions, we do have a duty to keep proportionate options under review,# she said.#We are publishing an updated strategic framework today, covering some of the issues have already summarised.#Finally, the First Minister urged the nation to stick as closely to the current guidance as possible in order to prevent the spread of COVID-. This includes undertaking a lateral flow test twice-weekly, and PCR testingyou develop symptoms, have a positive lateral flow or are contact traced.She also appealed to all those who have not yet taken up a COVID- vaccine, and are eligible, to please do so. title: greener orkney joins the community fridge network
story: Greener Orkney is pleased to announce that they will be joining the Community Fridge project, with the county#s first fridge opening next year.Launched by the Co-Op and Hubbub, the network is aimed at redistributing . million meals a year across the UK.Community Fridges are a  for sharing surplus food within a community to reduce food waste going to landfill. They are not means tested and are open to all. Community Fridges dfer from the vital role Food Banks play but can often be a complementary provision.There are over  community fridges across the UK with each fridge sharing one to four tonnes of food per month. Each year these community fridges redistribute  tonnes of food surplusand benefit up to , people. The project aims to increase the number of community fridges to .Greener Orkney has been awarded a grant of £, toward the initial setup costs.Angela Fitzpatrick, Greener Orkney treasurer, said: “The premise of a Community Fridge is simple – whatever items are available can be taken by anyone. As well as food sharing, Community Fridges give people opportunities to contribute through volunteering, learning new skills and sharing their existing skills.#Jane Nelson, chair of Greener Orkney, said: #Although the project will start small, we intend it to grow and estimate we will eventually need twenty volunteers to open and close the fridge each day, collect food from suppliers, and ensure the area is clean and tidy. We are reaching out to local charities and organisations to see how we can combine efforts to quickly expand this project.#Possible premises have been identied but first must be approved by Environmental Health to operate as a community fridge. Opening hours will depend on the number of volunteers and what donations are received. There will be a dedicated Facebook page and volunteers will update it daily to advise what food is available.If any organisations or iniduals are interested in helping with, or finding out more about the project, please reach out to Greener Orkney: greenerorkney@gmailcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Buses will turn left out of Travel Centre, left at Kiln Corner Roundabout, left at the Ayre Roundabout onto Great Western Road, rejoining routes on Pickaquoy Road .Works are planned for Outertown Road, Stromness, starting on Monday, November  to Thursday, December .Meanwhile, folk can expect roadworks on the A junction with Gorseness Road , on Friday, December  and Saturday .Roadworkers will be heading to the B road on Shapinsay between Housebay Cottage and Howe Farm, from Tuesday, December  to Thursday .On Monday and Tuesday - December, roadworks are planned for Old Finstown Road between Zions Loan and Kingsdale.The A St Mary’s, corner at The Inn, will be subject to roadworks from Monday, December  to Friday . The work is programmed to last for up to five days and will be carried out under road closure conditions in order for the folks involved to be as safe as possible. To reduce the impact of this, the closures will be restricted to am to .pm which should enable school transport to operate with a minimum of disturbance.Outwith the road closure times traffic will be restricted to using one side of the road and will be controlled by temporary traffic lights which will result in delays during busier periods.A ersion route will be in place via the Aand the B from St Andrews Primary School to the First Churchill Barrier.Stagecoach has advised that during the hours of am – :pm, the X commercial service from St Margarets Hope to Kirkwall will ert via the Kirkwall to Deerness road past St Andrews Primary School to the First Barrier and on to St Margaret’s Hope as per the existing timetable. Due to the change of route and possible disruptions, OIC asks passengers to allow   minutes on current scheduled times as there are likely to be delays.During the period of closure, there will be an additional X service in operation from Kirkwallas per the current timetable which will serve as far as St Marys and back for passengers residing in the Holm area. Therefore, the pick up  drop off point for passengers will be from Park of Ayre and therefore there will be no service between the First Barrier and Park of Ayre during the period of closure.Posters notying passengers of the ersions will be placed on the X service, Kirkwall Travel Centre and affected bus shelters. It should be noted that passengers can track buses across Orkney on the Stagecoach App which would provide accurate timings.OIC apologises for the inconvenience this will cause during the period of road closure. For further information on the X timetable during this time please contact Stagecoach on   or visitwww.orkney.gov.uk transport for timetable information.As for the council#s flagstone repairs, the works on John Street have been completed, with all barriers and signs now removed and the section reopened, today, Friday, November .In Victoria Street, from Bank Lane towards its junction with Ferry Road at the fountain works have been completed and reinstatements are curing with barriers expected to be removed next week. Access by the works area will been maintained.At Ferry Road, adjacent to the fountain, works have started and will continue next week, when the appropriate signs and barriers are erected. Access will be maintained.From Monday, November , works will commence on the section of Victoria Street from The Pier Bistro to the bottom of Church Road, with the section being closed to all vehicles. This section will be closed until the end of November.The works will then move onto Alfred Street, from December , starting at Hellihole Road junction, with the section up to the Lighthouse Pier access closed. This will mean vehicle access to Lighthouse Pier  South End will be via Ness Road.Throughout December works will continue along Alfred Street towards Mayburn Court, further updates will follow, as the works progress.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney down in infection rate rankings as 16 new cases confirmed
story: coronavirusOrkney down in infection rate rankings as  new cases confirmedNovember ,  at : pmA total of  new cases have been recorded in Orkney during the past  hours, according to figures published by the Scottish Government.While the county is continuing to record double digits daily, it has now dropped from first place to sixth in Public Health Scotland infection rate rankings.NHS Orkney has rolled out a revamped testing regime, this week, with the aim of reducing waiting times for results. There is now no need to phone and book a PCR test, with a drive-through self-testing service up and running at the COVID Assessment Centrein Kirkwall.A new phone number has also been introduced for the centre, for enquiries regarding testing. title: orkney ferries apologises for service disruption
story: newsOrkney Ferries apologises for service disruptionNovember ,  at : pmOrkney Ferries has apologised to its customers after booking staff in their Kirkwall office were asked to self-isolate by Test and Protect over the weekend.The closure led to a disruption in the ferry company#s booking system for customers in the North Isles, prompting Orkney#s MSP Liam McArthur to call for more progress to be made towards an online booking system.Giving an update on Tuesday afternoon, an Orkney Ferries spokeswoman said:#We apologise for the short term inconvenience caused by the closure of the Orkney Ferries for seven hours on Saturday.#HSE and Public Health Scotland#s guidance on office working processes have been followed to the letter by Orkney Ferries staff. Our staff are socially distanced and the office sanitised on a regular basis. Unfortunately, despite these measures Test and Protect contact tracers identied a number of close contacts and this posed a considerable and unprecedented strain on the system  As soon as staff were contacted they sought PCR tests # but had to self-isolate at home whilst they awaited the results.#At present the team are unable to operate outside of the office. Efforts have been ongoing over a number of months now to update IT systems within Orkney Ferries, to allow for more dynamic and flexible working practices in the future # including an online booking system # but this has been hampered by global IT shortages and supplier issues beyond the ability of the team to control or influence.#A service was restored at the first opportunity, albeit on a limited scale # and we are back to normal from today .#Whilst we appreciate the situation is far from ideal, we would ask for recognition that for the duration of this pandemic, our staff and crews have put considerable time and effort into supporting all our island communities # reacting at often short notice to regulatory changes to ensure the continuation of this important service.  We appreciate the frustration felt by our customers over the weekend but the abuse that has been received across social media and on the telephone is unacceptable and unfair.##That cannot continue. If the current contractors are unable to deliver what is needed, Orkney Ferries needs to replace them with someone who can. Given the leline nature of these services, the public and staff deserve a booking system fit for the job.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: rare chair returns home to orkney
story: A rare type of Orkney chair, made from oak couples used to extend St Magnus Cathedral, has been gted to the county#s flagship museum.The new donation to the Orkney Museum has caused great excitement among the curators and staff there. It was made by the Westray born chair maker David M. Kirkness , who ran a workshop in Kirkwall. By the late th century the straw-backed Orkney chair was unfashionable and the skill of making them was dying out.Janice Thomson of Tranent, East Lothian, donated the chair, which is understood to be a signicant addition to the museum#s collection — and its only example of a D.M. Kirkness chair.More in next week#s edition of The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: stromness hailed as an inspiration for other towns
story: The determination and ambition credited with making Stromness a better place to live has been hailed as an inspiration for other Scottish towns to follow.Work to improve the community is highlighted in a recently-launched website designed to empower and inspire those determined to make the nation’s towns stronger and more attractive.Scotland’s Towns Partnership’sTown Toolkit aims to help local authorities, community groups, social enterprises and businesses take action to build better communities. More than  people and organisations contributed to the Toolkit, whose development was supported by the Scottish Government.And Stromness will be among the communities highlighted as a prime example of success as the toolkit is discussed at the Scotland’s Towns Conference on Friday, November .The toolkit highlights how more than a decade of investment has helped revitalise the area, including the new £m Copland’s dock, the Orkney Research and Innovation Campus, and the creation of a new arts centre.Explaining the reasons for the community’s success, town planner Nick Wright, who developed the toolkit for STP and will highlight Stromness at the conference, said: “Everyone pulls together, making the most of every opportunity.“This is an ambitious community where people aren’t afraid to muck in and make things happen — with strong political will and a clear plan of modernising Stromness while maintaining its historical elegance.”That work includes the  year multi-million pound investments secured from the Lottery and Historic Environment Scotland to restore and modernise the town centre. Working with local landowners and organisations, these schemes restored  vacant or dilapidated historic buildings, improved shops, created new business spaces, and revitalised the town’s streets and spaces.Nick Wright added: “This toolkit is about sharing that wealth of experience from across the country — showing that you can do it because it’s been done before. It’s about how to make things happen — a one-stop-shop on how to make towns the best they can be.”While inspiring communities and groups, it is also hoped that the toolkit will prove useful for local authority officials working in planning, community development, leisure, transport and the economy when considering developments in their region, as well as for politicians at every level.For more information, go to www.towntoolkit.scot. Details about how to join in the discussions at Scotland’s Towns Conference, which runs from November  to , can be found at www.scotlandstowns.org scotlands_towns_conference_.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: world first for orkney made aviation fuel
story: Aviation fuel developed in Orkney has played a starring role in the RAF achieving a Guinness World Record.The RAF and Zero Petroleum have completed the world’s first successful flight using only synthetic fuel, which was developed in Orkney.In a world-first, an Ikarus C microlight aircraft, flown by Group Captain Peter Hackett, completed a short flight powered by synthetic gasoline at Cotswold Airport earlier this month.Zero Petroleum’s synthetic UL fuel is manufactured by extracting hydrogen from water and carbon from atmospheric carbon dioxide.Using energy generated from renewable sources like wind or solar, these are combined to create the synthetic fuel.Orkney-based firms IGTL and EMEC both contributed to the development of the synthetic fuel for the historic flight, at a temporary installation in Billa Croo, near Stromness.For more on this story, pick up this week#s The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. It is vital for our safety and prosperity that it can flourish. Yet the government treats it with hostility and suspicion, causing companies to move to countries with more science-friendly environments such as Belgium and Ireland.Dame Katersquos views echo similar comments made by the Prime Ministerrsquos former top aide, Dominic Cummings, and the Science and Technology Committee and the Health and Social Care Committee.Mr Cummings has been openly critical of how the early stages of the pandemic were dealt with by Government, and previously told Sky News that the Government system for dealing with crises is a ldquodisaster.A cross-party report published title: levelling up cash for shintys bught park in
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineNearly £ million, announced in the budget by chancellor Rishi Sunak, will go to developments in the Highland capital.Though the final details are still to be worked out, a new grandstand to replace the existing -year old structure, as well as facilities and a new shinty museum, could form part of the upgradeThe £ million package will go towards three schemes brought together under the umbrella of the Inverness Zero Carbon Cultural Regeneration project.The Northern Meeting Park and the Inverness Castle will also share in the funds, and it is hoped the cash can help attract more major events to the city.Shinty’s governing body, the Camanachd Association, and Inverness Shinty Club were involved in supporting the application, alongside Highland Council, Highle Highland and Highlands  Islands Enterprise.Steven Mackenzie, Camanachd Association president said: “The Camanachd Association look forward to hearing more detail on how this funding will improve facilities at the Bught Park.#I’d also like to take this opportunity to thank all parties involved in this successful funding application but particularly the Camanachd Association directors and staff who have worked closely with Inverness Shinty Club to ensure shinty was an integral part of the funding bid.”Derek Keir, Camanachd Association Chief Executive Officer said: “The news of the levelling up fund is a true testament to the power of working in partnership and we look forward to playing a key role in supporting the next steps as plans for the Bught Park progress.#I would like to pay particular tribute to our team at the Camanachd Associationwho have played a crucial role in these developments so far, to Inverness Shinty Club for their continued work in the community and to our partners at Highle Highland, Highland Council and HIE who all played a crucial role, we are very much excited about the next steps”.John Finlayson, Camanachd Association Director and Highland Councillor said: “I am delighted to hear such positive news for Inverness, the Highlands and the game of shinty and again the success of this bid shows the importance of partnership working between public bodies, sporting organisations and communities.“I am sure everyone across the Highlands and within the game of Shinty nationally, are excited by the prospect of upgraded facilities at the Bught Park which will help sustain and develop our sport in the years ahead.”Drew McNeil, Inverness Shinty Club development director said: “Investment in the development of the stadium is overdue.#It is extremely exciting but it needs to be tempered as the devil is in the detail and that’s not clear yet. We look forward to the future discussions on behalf of Shinty within the city affording Scotland’s first sport a facility befitting the cultural importance of our traditional sport.”

title: climate action group to hold skye bridge march and vigil in
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine, which formed shortly before the pandemic, is inviting people to show their solidarity with activists across the world in highlighting the need for urgent change to tackle the existential threat of climate change.Speaking to the Free Press during the first week of the COP UN Climate Change Conference in Glasgow, Skye Climate Action coordinator Anne MacLennan described the summit as “critically important” and was keen to emphasise that Saturday’s event should take place in a peaceful and respectable manner.#Saturday is the Global Day of Action for Climate Justice, and the themes are that we need to act, and act urgently, and there is also the huge justice issue,# she said.“The idea for the march is for us to leave the Kyleakin-end at  noon and to walk over the bridge by the pavements and walk back again.#It is really important that the event is peaceful, family-friendly, and respectful of everyone # I think it is a demonstration of the kind of society we want to head towards being, so we can live in a sustainable and equitable way. Issues of climate, bioersity, equity are all interconnected.She added: “I think it is more powerfulit is a peaceful walk.#Giving her views on the progress being made at the COP, she added: “There are some really hard-hitting things being said, so I hope the issues are getting through to people. It is important that those who are convincedcan demonstrate.#Addressing the potential for far-reaching consequences to impact people across the world, she said: #We are cushioned now to some extent, although people in the UK have had to suffer from flooding, wildfires, and drought.“Much of our food comes from overseas, andpeople will have to migrate and find somewhere  to live # so people will be moving around the world, so places that are nice and comfortable now might then receive other people.#A huge element of this issue is about all the youngsters and children # the more carbon we put into the atmosphere, the more trouble that they will have to face, meaning there will be less chance for them to turn the situation around.#This issue is critically important.”On Friday th November, as the conference is expected to be closing, there will be a candlelight vigil in Somerled Square in Portree from .-pm.Ms MacLennan added: “There is a sense that people want to show solidarity with what#s happening at COP in Glasgow, and they want to be able to express their concerns.#Holding it in Portree makes it more accessible for people in the north of the island, because Saturday#s march over the bridge is a long way for people further north to travel to be involved, especiallyit is a dreadful day.#For those unable to attend Saturday#s march over the bridge, everyone is of course welcome to walk over the bridge with signage at any point at the weekend.“It might be good for people to be wandering over the bridge to and fro at dferent times to help convey the message.”

title: climate change and the hebrides the rising sea and an eerily prophetic
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFor those acquainted with Gaelic oral lore, it cannot be denied that there is something intensely perceptive, and eerily prophetic, about the traditions tied to the steady ingress of the sea.Since time immemorial, the mental record-keeping of a coastal people has documented and predicted the near imperceptible, yet near constant, rise of the waters since the Ice Age. century.In Tobar an Dualchais, there are numerous recordings illustrating similar examples where the sea has conquered the land.In one example from , Dòmhnall MacCuinn and Dòmhnall Ailean MacCuinn were recorded describing old domestic ruins seen at extreme low tides over a mile from the shore in An t-Ìochdar .These homesteads must have once been on dry land, they surmise.In Tracks   , the collector Dòmhnall Eairdsidh Dòmhnallach of the School of Scottish Studies asks Dòmhnall Alasdair Johnson about submerged places near An t-Ìochdar, including Sgeir na h-Àtha – The Skerry of the Barn.Similar shore names which incorporate terrestrial features dot the seascape of Uist and evidence the widely held belief that the machair once stretched much further into the west.Anxieties tied to coastal le were not only informed by past experience and day-to-day observation they also manested themselves in people’s visions of the future.There is a prophecy, for example, retold by Dòmhnall Alasdair Johnson in Track . It presages that the Ìochdar shoreline will soon be as far inland as A’ Bhuaile Dhubh and An Càrnan, close to where the old Church of Scotland is.He remarks that such an outcome isn’t all that farfetched, considering the severity of coastal erosion in the area.Alexander Carmichael, the folklorist and compiler of Carmina Gadelica, also published several climactic prophecies. He was fascinated by these histories and repeatedly drew attention to the submerged remains of houses, temples and tree-roots in his writings.A poem collected in Lìonacuithe in  prophesies the flooding of the Atlantic: “The walls of the churches shall be the fishing-rocks of the people, while the resting-place of the dead shall be a forest of tangles, among whose mazes the pale-faced mermaid, the marled seal, and the brown otter shall race and run and leap and gambol, like the children of men at play.”The approaching catastrophe so arrestingly depicted in this verse parallels many of the same fears voiced by coastal communities today.Indeed, such predications are the reality for hundreds of millions of people across the globe. The most recent UN report on climate change published in August  warned that we could see the ocean ascend nearly  metre by the end of the century.Such outcomes will threaten many of these societies existentially. Island nations such as the Males and Tuvalu will disappear.Cities, including New York City, Shanghai and Kolkata, will be exposed to coastal flooding by . Bangladesh could lose up to a fth of its land mass, displacing -million people. century is our frightening reality.In Scotland, low-lying areas with soft coasts of machair are particularly vulnerable, especially those at the edge of the Atlantic like Islay, Tiree and Uist.In addition to the constant erosion on the western edges of Uist, there is a further struggle in low-lying areas.Drainage is critical, as any crofter will tell you.Sufficient and well-maintained drains allow water to flow to the ocean. When there is heavy rainfall – a trend that is due to intensy in the UK in the future, drains alleviate inland flooding.In South Uist, a large drain is called a “lig”, a term associated with letting water.There are several main lige systems in South Uist and some are apparent in placenames. There is An Lige Mòr in Dalabrog, An Lige Mòr in Loch Aoineart, Loch Bun an Ligidh in Dreumasdal and Loch an Ligidh at the western terminus of Loch Bì.While the ligidhean today act as drains, most of these sizeable watercourses were likely built as canals to transport goods.This is reflected in the oral tradition of Uist that most of the machair lochs were once connected by ligidhean.In Track , Dòmhnall MacAonghais of Taobh a Deas Ghleann Dail credits the Norse with the original construction of the canals, which ran from Poll a’ Charra to An t-Ìochdar. He says that the waterways were used in place of roads. Track  runs into Track , where Dòmhnall says that there were three places where the Norse wintered their fleets, at An t-Ìochdar, An Ròdha Glas in Cill Donnain, and at Poll a’ Charra.Interestingly, these places correspond to locations where there are manmade drains running to the Atlantic Ocean.Regardless of their actual origin, which is the subject of ongoing research, the ligidhean of South Uist endure as critical infrastructure against flooding.As sea levels rise, however, the drains are rendered less effective due to the reduction in the height between the inland water table and the sea.This gets so bad during some springtides that saltwater can even flow back into the freshwater system, risking the salinisation of the ecosystem.The threat of climate change and sea-level rise unites coastal communities across the world.It is imperative that the COP debates take notice of these voices and reflect on the cumulative experience and knowledge of these societies.Gaelic is only one voice, and there are numerous other climate threads and themes, from within Tobar an Dualchais and without, which couldn’t be included into such a short article.We can only guess at the breadth and depth of information about climate change that exists in other endangered and indigenous languages across the globe.This information is not only relevant to fully understanding the crises we face they may also point to a way out of them.

title: frightful fun for all at hallowena 2021
story: THE People’s Park, Ballymena will host one of the scariest nights of the year on Friday, October , from pm to .pm.The free event, organised by Mid and East Antrim Borough Council, will thrill and chill with a packed programme of spooktacular activities for your little monsters to enjoy, with a huge walking dragon, fire juggling display, a fancy dress competition, a kiddies funfair, live music from The VIPs and a spooky illumination trail.You can sink your fangs into some sweet treats or tasty hot food to beat those Halloween hunger pangs, while the fun and festivities will finish with a fangtastic fireworks finale at .pm.Why not have your own #MEAdventure in the park  Outdoor areas including the brand new play equipment will be accessible during the event and there will be a free kiddies fun fair to entertain your little terrors.Wandering ghouls and spine tingling figures will be ready to spook you at every turn with a few hair-raising special additions.Follow the extended spooky illumination trail throughout the park and bump into some familiar characters along the way!Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, encouraged everyone to join in the Hallowena fun: “It is a great delight for us to be able to safely welcome our community to events this year and the Hallowena celebrations are always among the most popular on Council’s entertainment programme.“There is literally something for ghosts and goblins of all ages to enjoy on Friday  October in the stunning People’s Park in Ballymena, and I am really excited about the evening.“I am privileged to welcome everyone in our community to the park for some spooktacular fun, and I encourage those attending to observe the necessary public health guidelines so that we can protect ourselves and those around us.”There are over  off-street car park spaces within a -minute walk of People’s Park so make an evening of it with a visit to any of the fantastic shops or restaurants in the town.Parking for blue badge holders is available from pm at the People’s Park council car park off the Ballymoney Road.To help with a safe set-up of the site People’s Park will be closed to all members of the public on Friday  October until the event starts at pm.For everyone’s safety dogs, alcohol or fireworks are not permitted in the park and under s must have a responsible adult with them.Admission is free and no tickets are required.Visitors to the Hallowena event are asked to use the hand sanitisers provided and observe social distancing. Temperature scanning will take place on entry to the park.Please do not attend the eventyou have any symptoms of Coronavirus. More information on COVID- safety measures, including lateral flow testing, can be found at www.midandeastantrim.gov.ukVisit midandeastantrim.gov.uk Hallowena for regular updates ahead of the big night.Throughout , Council is hosting a programme of events under the NI  umbrella to celebrate  years since the formation of Northern Ireland.These events, exhibitions and community initiatives are all aimed at showcasing and championing culture, heritage, education, history, and future prosperity throughout the Mid and East Antrim Borough.
